title: Table Frontal

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of silk, warp-float faced 3:1 'z' twill weave with gold-leaf-over-lacquered-paper strips supplementary facing wefts and supplementary pile warps forming cut voided velvet; top border: cotton, plain weave; painted inscription; lined with cotton, plain weave; painted inscription.

medium_display: Silk, warp-float faced 3:1 'Z' twill weave with gold-leaf-over-lacquered-paper strips supplementary facing wefts and supplementary pile warps forming cut voided velvet; top border: cotton, plain weave; painted inscription; lined with cotton, plain weave; painted inscription
inscriptions: Inscription translation (on top front): Publicly purchased for the Chaodian shrine of the Fujun hui [a fraternal association]; (on reverse): Jiaqing, ninth year [1804], twelfth month, first day of the moon: All the jia [neighborhood association] publicly purchased [this piece] valued at three ounces of silver. Those in charge commonly agreed on this resolution not to permit private use [of it] also not to permit transfer or loan to others.  If, after investigation, [this charge has been found to be violated, there will be] a fine of three ounces of silver.  Each should find it suitable to obey this resolution. Respectfully recorded.  In the Chaodian shrine of the Fujun hui, the jia, the one in charge and everybody else bows and presents.
credit_line: Gift of Joseph Adams in memory of Edith Almy Adams
publication_history: John E. Vollmer, "Clothed to Rule the Universe: Ming and Qing Dynasty Textiles at The Art Institute of Chicago," published in conjunction with the exhibition, Art Institute of Chicago Museum Studies 26, no. 2 (2000): 39-40, 65, cat. 39, plate XXI.
exhibition_history: Art Institute of Chicago, Elizabeth F. Cheney and Agnes Allerton Textile Galleries, Clothed to Rule the Universe: Ming and Qing Dynasty Textiles at The Art Institute of Chicago, Sept. 13, 2000–Jan. 2, 2001, cat. 39.
